So we ordered at the counter and the person who took our order had no personality. Definitely not meant to be in the service industry because there was no service. He was not friendly and made it seem like it was an inconvenience that we were ordering food at a food establishment. 

Then we ordered our breakfast which was not too expensive but not cheap either. And when the food arrived it was mediocre at best. 

I will definitely not be coming back here again.
author: Chris D.

description:
Great place to go prior to an event at AT&T Park. We went here before Beyonce/Jay-Z concert and it is a very chill spot. Got the cheeseburger + onion rings. The food wasn't bad - nothing outstanding though. 

The best part about the Java House is the back patio. Fits a ton of people, drinks are reasonably priced, and a great view of the water. After having a few drinks and eating, take a 10 minute walk over to AT&T park and begin festivities.
author: Albert K.

description: Breakfast here was easy and delicious: huevos rancheros. They really jazz up their chili for the dish -- it includes ground beef and wine, which gives breakfast an unexpected added complexity.  The view on the water was great too and I love the history of the place!
author: Mike V.

description:
Amazing : authentic.
What goes together better then those two words? Nothing! Walked a few miles around San Fran and found this cute little place with a really cool bar outside. Stop by you won't regret it.
author: Breanna S.

description:
Came here for brunch. Drinks are good. Stick with the breakfast food. Eggs and bacon and good. Pancakes are so-so. The chili cheeseburger was really bad. It was under seasoned so it was just a muck of ground beef, goop and beans. 

The location is nice. Right next to parking along the pier. Nice and sunny. Prices aren't bad either.

I would say enjoy the price and atmosphere, but be careful about what you order.
author: Peter T.

description:
A funky place, with funky birds. ( Mostly pigeons, but a sea gull sat next to me once, and I accosted by a pelican in front of the entrance. )

Not everyone's style, to be sure, but the crunchy sourdough bagguette-like bread was delicious as a base for the cheeseburger.
author: George T.

description:
I went to Red`s yesterday, 4th of July, because a close friend recommend it. It was my first time in San Francisco so we had a little trouble finding it initially. Then we asked a lady at the train station and she directed us the right way and said we couldn't miss it. 
It's a small building that you can't miss for sure. We were surprised at the small menu, basically hamburgers, hotdogs and fries. I love a good burger but they had a sign posted that they don't do lettuce and tomato. I was disappointed because I like a leafy burger. Anyway, I ordered a cheese burger. It came with mustard, pickles and onions. My best friend just ordered a plain hotdog because she doesn't like mustard, onions or pickles and didn't want to have just a meat patty and bread. We also ordered fries and 2 sodas. It was $20!
The restaurant is small but has an outdoor patio the kinda Has a view. My burger turned out to be really good but I think it Was mostly because it was on sourdough bread. I was definitely full after. It wouldn't have been my first choice to eat since it was my first time in SF. I would really only recommend to locals to watch the game and grab a beer.
author: Tierzah P.

description:
I drive by every day, so I randomly stopped by for a cup of coffee, but ended up getting a burger as well.

Burger
I was excited about the burger as I was ordering b/c I could see the grill in the background charring up some greasy delicious looking patties. However, the burger lacked flavor and seriously tasted like a McDonalds burger, but on a french roll. It isn't bad, but I wouldn't go back for a burger.
author: Alfonzo J.

description:
Respect to this 80+ year old San Francisco institution  but the burgers are horrible. I have no qualms about giving this filthy dive one star but I'll bump it up to two just to be nice. The cheese isn't melted and the meat smells and taste funny.

Just because something is old doesn't make it good. I come for the food not the ghost of decades past.

It is very inexpensive and you can't beat their burgers for the price. If you're looking for a spot the locals come this might be it. I have a sneaking suspension that the Americas Cup and its thousands of people only two feet from the front door will do nothing to clean this dump up.
author: Justin S.

description:
The hamburger was simply not worth serving. The bartender and staff were friendly enough. 

Also, for an establishment with "java" in its name, I'd think they do more than serve coffee out of self serve dispensers.
author: Combi C.

description:
when I saw RJH on No Reservation a few years ago what caught my eye was their burger on what looked like a hoagie roll. burgers on a hoagie, grinder or sub roll was popular with east coast dives who wanted just one type bread for their hot or cold sandwiches and burgers. for me there was no better way to have a burger and before the gourmet burger craze you have to admit buns were pretty boring. so having a burger on an italian roll with perfectly melted american cheese or cheddar with sauteed onions was just something else. it was a burger that you couldn't get in restaurants or chains, and you know what you still can't, but hey..., you can get pretzel buns at wendys now. so to get my east coast hoagie burger fix i make them at home.


RJH is my kind of place that i would be a regular to. if i was a baseball Giants fan id probably stop in before or after a game. here's the but... next time i would ask them to cook the onions for me and i would wait for the burger right at the pick up window and eat it while walking back to my table. why? the sauteed onions would add a little sweetness to the bite and would go great with their sourdough roll. their raw onions, pickles, mustard on a sourdough equaled tons of similar flavor in a bite. also,... the reason why you have to have it right away, their cheese. a great cheeseburger needs to have perfectly melted cheese, it needs a "little" pull factor in a bite. the cheese on my burger dried out by the time i took my first bite, as if my burger patty wasn't hot enough to melt it properly. 


the owners probably could care less because i'm sure they have their regulars to keep the business going, but a little change in cooking methods would go a long way in terms of the quality of the food. 

*can't beat the view...
author: NYSD G.

description:
REAL corned beef hash.

If that's not enough to give out five stars, I don't know what is.

The C. and I spent a lovely Sunday breakfast here before our foraging trip.  Funny thing, I never knew there was a restaurant out in those parts.  I was most happily enlightened.

Sadness came, however, when we left and I forgot to photograph the space heater building (aka Rincon One) rising out of the bridge ramp, the top completely obscured in heavy fog.  My description will simply have to do for you.  Maybe one day circumstances and weather patterns will repeat itself and I can take it then.

5 stars, all round.
author: Lorrayne L.

description:
I HAD to give this place a 1 star, because that's the lowest possible rating on Yelp. First of all, I'd never expect even somewhat decent service from such a dive, so I won't even comment on how horrendous the service is here. Came here after hearing the rave reviews about them serving the best burgers in The City and even watching Anthony Bourdain drool over them on two different episodes of his travel show on TV, so I ordered their most popular Double Cheeseburger on their sourdough roll. 

All I can say is this was by far THE WORST BURGER EVER. Rubbery, flavorless, and thawed out "beef" patties that were drenched in such nasty re-used grease that you could taste the remnants of all the previous meats that were cooked in it. YUK!!! Safe to say I will NEVER, EVER go back here again!
author: Mostafa S.

description:
Breakfast before the Giants played the Mets. Got the pancake platter, which was just enough for me. It consist of one very large not-to-sweet pancake, two eggs (overeasy please!) and I kid you not -- a handful of bacon strips. 

I swear, I had like six strips of bacon on that baby! Now, don't get me wrong, I love bacon as much as the next girl, but I can't handle all that delicious artery clogging goodness in the morning. So I shared it with my cousins like any sane person would do. :) 

Will probably have to come back for their lunch-type foods for another game, or just grab a beer in the beer garden out in the back on the pier. 

GO GIANTS!
author: Joanie S.

description: 4 stars for the cheap beers you can get from their back patio! However, I didn't enjoy their burger, which was just meat, cheese, pickles, and some diced onions on a roll. The roll is too big for the meat patty, so there are a few bites where you are just eating bread, and the patty is pretty tasteless, even if you add ketchup and mustard. Fries and onion rings are good, but nothing special. I would recommend coming to Red's for the cheap beer, or if you like a meaty burger patty and enjoy eating them on rolls. However, there usually is a decent sized line and it moves slowly since they give you your order right away, and hold up the line until the burgers are ready. If you just want beer, bypass the line in the front and head straight to the back patio area!
author: Amy D.

description:
Bf had been wanting to try for awhile. We swung in here just before closing and got a seat outside.

The burger was good. Didn't like the sourdough roll it was on (aka too much bread). Too much mustard on the burger, and I didn't understand the guy when he asked me about the mustard. Normally, just ketchup and mayo please.
Fries were awesome, like McDonalds. and I fortunately eat McD's only once a year, but I certainly remember what the fries taste like. The chili cheese fries were not awesome. It was like canned chili and no cheese.
author: Abigail W.

description:
Ifyou want to get a tasty burger and fries and ice cold beer at a good price before the Giants game.  This is the place to go.

Red's Java House is located south of the bay bridge.  They serve mostly burgers, hot dogs , fish in chips and of course fries.  They offer fairly reason price deals on the above plus nice cold brew if that is your beverage of choice before a baseball game.  

It's a no frills diner with both indoor and(outdoor dining.  They have a separate bar so you can get a refill on your pint or pitcher of beer without waiting in line with  the people ordering your food.

Also, it's located by the peir so you a great bay view that really adds to your dining experience.

Although you still have quite a bit of a walk to get to the ballpark after dinner.
author: Chuck J.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend on a Sunday to grab a quick bite to eat. 

We shared the corned beef breakfast sandwich. Overall it was yummy, but had a few too many potatoes and not enough corned beef! Next time, I'll also ask for just egg whites. My boyfriend tried the coffee which he said was not good, and ended up tossing it after a few sips. A few negatives are the tables are sticky (could use a good wipe down but it's expected at a dive-y place like this) and there are a lot of flies out back near the bar. Pluses are the fast service, interesting pictures on the walls, and TV in the back.
author: Siv L.

description:
It's not as sketchy as you think it is!

Interesting hamburger. A) It's on sour dough. B.) They only serve it with mustard and onions. Result: a very sour but interesting burger. 

Good place to grab dinner on the way to the ball game.

Unexpectedly lots of seating. There's seating in the shack, there is covered seating out back and outdoor seating even beyond that. The outdoor seating is on some dock and it has a nice view of the bridge and the bay.

I didn't check for a bathroom but I did see a porta-poty - so I wouldn't be going here for emergency restroom needs. 

They take credit card.
author: Gee H.

description:
Okay the food is a 1 or a 2, BUT the service is fast and good (as good as a walk up counter can be). The atmosphere is  priceless.  Out in the sunshine on Pier 30 away from all the fisherman's wharf yahoo's.  This place is mostly men getting their grub on...but today it included this little lady (ehem, it's my birthday so I am taking some liberties with the word "little") for her birthday lunch. I went single with cheese, but the better play would have been to split the double cheese with someone - lessons for next time. There is  just too much bread to meat ration on the single - and while the bread is a fine and fresh sourdough roll, it needed the heft of one extra patty to round it out.
 
As an exercise in excess, we also got the chili cheese fries to split - nothing special - but as it usually goes with chili fries (or nachos for that matter) the first couple bites are the best, then the soggy factor hits, and you keep eating b/c they are there not b/c they are anything special.
 
Thanks to Susan for Lunch - a cold beer would have been delightful but sadly my company eschews drinking during working hours ;(
author: Amy W.

description:
Red's Java House is a throwback to a time when you didn't have to worry about the face of the animal you were eating, or the number of calories in your daily meal, or before you could review a business on a website for all of humanity to see.  Red's is a simple restaurant in a very complex city.  There is no pretention about Red's:  it is what it is.  Many people may walk, drive or bike by Red's without giving it a thought, but they are missing out on a great diner.  

Walk in, order a burger, fries and a drink, and sit down.  The food is not fancy, but it's tasty to the core.  And, for a fairly expensive city, the prices aren't too bad.  If you're watching a Giants game down the road, come by a little early and eat at Red's.  The meal you'll get there is a lot better and cheaper than anything you'll get at AT&T Park.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Reds,
You rock.  My grandfather took my father here, my father took me here as a child.  Now that I get to wear big boy pants I come here every time I have an excuse to be on the embarkadero.  Burger on a sourdough roll.. perfect.  The fact that the menu reads: "Double cheeseburger, Fires & Bud $8.00" makes me happy inside.  Reds, you are the perfect no excuse needed burger and a beer place to go.  Thank you for your many years of service.
author: Dr I.

description:
Fish.
Chips.
Tarter.
Vinegar.

Sitting on the dock by the bay, wastin' time....

Doesn't get much better than this!
author: Sara D.

description:
This is a perfect representation of what San Francisco is. Massive bridge above, water close by, the squawk of seagulls and other sea fowl, the smell of salty fresh air and delicious, but simple food.

Don't be deterred by the hole in the wall look, or the location. This is a must visit restaurant. The burgers are greasy and delicious and surrounded by fresh French bread. The beers are ice cold, the prices are reasonable and the view is to die for. 

Please make sure that you make Red's a must on your next visit to SF. It will make you appreciate life just a bit more than you already do.
author: Steve S.

description:
If there is a place close to the ballpark where Philly and Giants fans can coexist in jovial drinking under a setting SF sun before a game, then Red's Java House is probably it. 

Red's is a low-key fast-food joint so don't expect anything more than that. Instead of a regular bun, burgers are served on a baguette. I would suggest the double cheese because the ratio of bread to meat is a little unbalanced with a single. Also expect ketchup to be your veggie accompaniment. There are better beer deals in the area but the patio makes it special. They do have a happy hour though which brought a pitcher of Anchor to around $16 I believe. 

Red's isn't fancy. It never claimed to be. It's about beer and food that pairs with beer. What it is great for are lazy afternoons under the sun, or a pregame spot before heading to the ballpark.
author: Jon L.

description:
Location Location Location.  How cool is this shack that's been there forever on an old abandoned pier.  It's a great place to grab a burger and a beer and watch some seagulls.  I like many food tourists, got wind of this place from Anthony Bourdain's No Reservations.  It just looked like a cool place and it most definitely is.

No frills to this menu.  In fact it's pretty take it or leave it.  They have a sign that says NO LETTUCE AND TOMATO on our burgers.   Now I love my veggies on my burger, but I respect a place that has a my way or the highway mentality.  The only thing you'll be offered is pickles, onions, and mustard.  So I went with a double cheeseburger, which comes on their Sourdough bread roll.  You need the double to fill that sucker up as it's one solid piece of bread.  The burgers are on the thin side, so most definitely get the double.  Cheese content was very impressive.  Not sure how many slices of cheddar cheese were used, but it not only covered the burgers well but also any exposed parts of the bread.  Let's not fool ourselves the star of this sandwich is the bread.  The burgers?  Meh, just ok, not overly seasoned, or anything very remarkable about them.  But the bread is some great sourdough, and you throw any kind of hot meat patty and lots of melted cheese on it, it's going to be good. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/reds-java-house-san-francisco?select=Mn5Y7zMYZ7oKXkKLgpQ3yQ#VDtQn-MQXYAfpJa32pQujQ

I also liked their fries in a McDonald's kind of way.  I'm stealing from another reviewer here that compared them to Macky D's, but sure enough that's what they look and taste like, except better - like the way McDonald's fries tasted 20 years ago.  

I grabbed a hot dog as well.  It's topped the same way as their burgers, but this one was missing their great bread and was on a sesame seed bun.  It was nothing special and the dog got lost in all the cheese.  I'd skip this, and make sure anything you order comes on the sourdough bread.  Also make sure you head to the back of the shack and sit outside or you're missing the vibe of the place. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/reds-java-house-san-francisco#R1z0wNRMTv1lsWUL-gDAVg
author: Dave G.

description: Don't go to this place, My family got disrespected by the manager and he's an as@&$#¥£% and don't even deserve to get a star at all period (yelf says "u can't leave a msg w/o a rating"). This place sucks!!
author: FL A.

description:
I think this one of those places that you either "get" or don't. We got it. My husband and I walked down from the Ferry Building after taking the Ferry from Oakland on our trip up the coast on Highway 1. It was a blast walking with all the Giants fans that were on their way to the game and many of them stopped at Red's. 

No, there's no lettuce and tomato, just like at In-N-Out there's no bacon, no onion rings, no side salad...etc. It's ridiculous to call a place out based on what they don't have when they tell you clearly before you order. If it's a deal breaker for you, leave.

We had already sampled food at the Ferry Building so we split a cheeseburger and fries. Tasty sourdough roll went well with the meat, cheese and toppings and the fries were well-cooked. Patio was great. 
Watch out for the seagulls!
author: Laura W.

description:
Moved away from San Francisco several years ago...I miss the burgers at Red's.

Whether it is the sour dough bun or the tasty little burgers, something here makes this place the real deal.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Looks sketch from outside, but inside is better. It's a great place to grab a beer (or just coffee and a sandwich) while walking to AT&T Park, but be warned that it'll get crowded before a game. The line goes out the door and down the street.

They even have a decent veggie burger, which was, for me, unexpected.

It's a very small place so if you have a large group, I'd recommend nominating a spokesperson to go in and get the food. Also, with a large group expect to sit outside.
author: S S.

description: I love the food here! The cheese burgers on sourdough bread are amazing! The guy serving us was super nice, even though we were all in dodger gear! Thank you for defending us from the obnoxious  giant  fan that was using profanity!
author: Martha M.

description: My husband used to come here when he was younger and said they had great burgers. I didn't think they were anything special and he said he'll probably never go back. The place seemed kind of unclean with lots of flies in the bar and hallway leading outside. Plus the ketchup and mustard sit out for who knows how long outside. I'll pass on returning.
author: Ginelle H.

description: In need of a quick easy breakfast by the ballpark, we wandered in to just take a look and ended up staying for breakfast. This is a decent greasy spoon diner option in a neighborhood without a lot of food options. Service is friendly and quick and the food is good. I imagine things slow down on game days, but on a Sunday morning, our food came out fast. Also, there's a back porch outdoor dining option that is dog friendly.
author: Alice H.

description:
Starting off my birthday weekend with free tickets to the Giants game, my boyfriend and I stumbled our butts into here before walking over. I have been craving a burger for quite awhile. There are not a lot of places where I will just go to and get a burger. I have seen Red's Java House so many times when going to the games, it was awesome to finally come here after years living in the Bay. 

I was pleasantly surprised when I got my burger. I didn't read the reviews of this restaurant because it was a spur of the moment stumble into eatery for us. So when I looked at my burger all tucked away into a sourdough bun, I had a 'whoa - wth' moment. Of course complete with its Budweiser (really?), I nom nom my way through the food. Let me just say it is VERY different but it was not bad at all. If I could, I would order another one, but gee it was pricey. 

Makes me miss the $1.50 burgers we got in Seattle. By the way, I am completely basing my entire review on my recollection. I had a little pre-game drinking action before coming here, so insert this under drunken eating category.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Meh .  When they say "do you want everything on that burger" , they mean onions mayo and mustard . This establishment boycotts lettuce and tomato , so BYOL&T. 
Weird
author: Jung H.

description:
Went to Red's before a game, Go Dodgers!!! I had the cheesebuger. Very good burger on sourdough bread. Great place to hang out before the game, a visit is a must. 

Nice cold beer at this place too.
author: Rafael Z.

description: Their food isn't great (low end greasy dinner), but it gets the job done, and sitting with a beer on their pier on a sunny day is one of the greatest pleasures lunch can provide.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Red's Java House is really the closest thing we have to Cheers on this side of the country...

Makin' your way in the world today takes everything you've got. 
Takin' a break from all your worries, sure would help a lot. 
Wouldn't you like to get away? 
Sometimes you want to go 
Where everybody knows your name, 
And they're always glad you came. 
You wanna be where you can see, 
Our troubles are all the same 
You wanna be where everybody knows 
Your name. 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ePcTjab1uik&feature=related

Oh sure, it's a dive. And OK, maybe they don't know my name since I don't frequent the place like Norm...NORM!  But there's no getting around the fact that it's comfortable in here. It's a place where you can come unshaven, unshowered and with last week's boxers on...not that I would know. And still, the order guy is friendly as all get out. Red's is an institution for us long-timers in the Bay Area.

Over the years, I've had my fill of burgers and beers with friends I barely remember and ex-colleagues I would rather forget. We would gather the dilapidated tables on the dock and spend a few hours staring at either the underside of the Bay Bridge or the adjacent vacant parking lot. And of course, what would Red's be without the flurry of obstreperous pigeons and seagulls competing for the leftovers under the umbrellas?

But I have to tell you that I actually like to come here on a Sunday morning when it's empty and get the $5.50 Breakfast Special - two scrambled eggs, two sausage patties and a pancake with plenty of butter and syrup. Such a deal. It ain't gourmet food, not by a long shot (see the photo). In fact, it's probably the type of grub you get if you're in the mess hall at San Quentin and your cellmate starts to look pretty to you...not that I would know. But it hits the spot, and you can get free refills on the coffee to sustain you on the walk along the Embarcadero...NORM!

You wanna be where you can see, 
Our troubles are all the same 
You wanna be where everybody knows 
Your name.

FOOD - 3 stars...grub food the way I like it
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...a dive on a dock, but oh I like it
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendlier than Sam Malone or Woody or even Coach and definitely more than Carla
TOTAL - 4 stars...just because you wanna be everyone knows your name
author: Ed U.

description:
Let me start off by saying I've never had the food here - this is a place I go to drink.

The place is perfect for an after work beer on a sunny beautiful day.  There is a really large outdoor area which is great for big groups and you have the option of being in the shade or being in the beaming sunlight.

They have pretty standard beers on tap, Lagunitas IPA, Anchor Steam, Shock Top, etc - nothing fancy and their cocktails are ok.

Honestly I only go because my co-workers like to check it out every now and then after work.  I always have fun, but it's nothing special. 

Bottom line: If you like drinking in large groups, outside, AND for a reasonable price - this place gets the job done.
author: Lauren B.

description:
This is the anti-gourmet burger.  No aioli, no lettuce/tomatoes.  Just your basic greasy burger on a sourdough roll that provides the SF touch.  Burger was standard, nothing home to write about.  Inside it had cheese, mustard and pickles.  The sourdough roll portion was unique about this burger if anything.  The fries were nice and crispy.  You want mayo?  They have packets along with relish on their shelf of condiments if needed.  Great location right on the bay with the bridge lookin right at you.  There are signs about the birds being aggressive and will take your food if you're not looking. 

Overall this is like a dive bar, meat and potato and beer kinda place.  Dont expect anything fancy here or else you'll be disappointed.
author: Ivan D.

description:
I got the fish and chips which were good but I felt it was overpriced. Also I was disappointed that I couldn't get the crab sandwich, which they apparently only sell for breakfast. Parking is a nightmare but that's to be expected. The view of the water is nice but limited by the huge, overpriced parking lot next to the restaurant. 

Overall, kind of "meh" but if I was a local I might come back for a the crab sandwich just to give it a try.
author: Brittany M.

description:
Tourist trap with mediocre food.

Onion rings were standard frozen food service garbage. Tasted like breaded rubber bands. Chili cheese burger was a stew of beans with a sourdough roll. The chili was bland and flavorless, the roll could not be eaten by hand because it was drenched, and the burger was a disappointing gray meat patty.

At least I can cross this off my list and say "I've been there."
author: .Alan Y.

description:
We were in town for a Giants game and some friends suggested we meet at Red's before the game. This small shack on the Embarcadero gets pretty busy. I can't say much about the menu since all I had were the onion rings. The onion rings were okay. They were served hot but kinda reminded me of Burger King onion rings. Needless to say they satisfied my urge for something salty and fried. Drinks are pretty cheap and also sold by the bucket. Like everyone else noted, the view from the patio is pretty but only if you don't mind sitting 5 feet away from a porto-potty.

Sidenote: If your looking for parking for the Giants game, the lot next to Red's charges $10-$20.
author: Cindy S.

description:
This place is a greasy spoon if I've ever seen one. I walked in and felt filthy and seeing and smelling the food just disgusted me. 

My cousin and I walked through to the back patio and found a bartender ice grilling us as we walked towards the bar. No smile, no hello. Just staring. Being in San Francisco, I wasn't sure if this was a come on type thing or if he was just a big a-hole. Either way, it made me pretty uncomfortable. 

Then we ordered our beers and got tiny 12 ounce plastic cups of beer for like $5-6. What a joke. The patio is nice, but you'll go broke trying to get drunk and chill here before a game.
author: Clayton A.

description:
Was out getting exercise and walking the dogs along the Embarcadero and decided that I had to finally try the Double Cheeseburger and beer.  There was no price on the sign out front but quickly found out a dbl cheese is $4.79 and $5.00 for an Anchor Steam.  

The burger is served on tasty SF sourdough and the burgers are probably the frozen variety with pickles, onions and mustard.  There is clearly a sign by the register that says no Lettuce or Tomatoes.  The problem with the burger is that bread is too big and chewy so when you bite on one side, the meat slips to the other and next thing you have a big mess and the thing is falling apart.  You will definitely need lots of napkins.  

I would say the food and beer is average for a restaurant and we all need to help keep these historic places in business.  The view is fabulous and was a mix of tourist on bikes, a few locals in the bar area watching the 49ers.  The bar looks good and it's close to my house.  I will probably be back if I want to stay low key and get some artery clogging greasy food and some good booze.
author: James H.

description: A San Francisco institution. If you don't get it, then leave.
author: Nica L.

description:
I lived on Howard Street and I was very disappointed to walk 1/2 mile to Red's "Java" House only to find some sorry-ass generic coffee in a vacuum pump container....I love coffee...I wanted "java" from Red's world-famous, blah-blah-blah...

Very let down on the coffee.

That said, had a breakfast of some good pancakes, eggs and (very) good french fries.
author: Lowell Z.

description: I LOVE this place!! We always stay around this area in the city and Reds is the place that we like for breakfast (burger with an egg on it) lunch (amazing burger and giants style garlic fries) or just to have a great bloody mary! The only toppings on the burger are mustard, onions and pickles.  The burger is served on some of the most delicious sourdough bread and this is a must stop in sf!!
author: Ashlee D.

description:
I had neither any idea that Anthony Bourdain was affiliated with this place in any way or fashion nor any reason to believe he should affiliate himself with this place when I came down here to meet an old college friend I hadn't seen for a few years, and I feel kinda bad about writing a bad review about this place since my friend really hyped up the place and seemed to like it so much, but meh, to each his own.

First of all, the location of the restaurant is kinda... ambiguous. It's located on Pier 30, which almost right under a huge overpass bridge, and the "pier" itself is more of a parking lot, rather than an actual "let's walk out and be close to the ocean" pier; the view from both inside and outside seating areas of the restaurant is obstructed by either a building or other man-made structures so it's really hard to sit down and have a "fisherman's wharf" kinda experience here.

Second, although I like the no-nonsense menu and the prices, the food was really bland and uninspiring. I got the chili cheeseburger because both my friend and the guy working at the counter recommended it; the burger came in a sourdough bun with a small cheese-melted patty and lots of chili on top. Not to mention that it didn't help that I was lost as to how to get the soggy greasy solid concoction into my stomach, the only silverware they provide here are cheap plastic knives and forks which proved quite ineffective when it came to cutting through two layers of sourdough. When I finally did manage to cut through the sourdough with my plastic utensils, I accidentally cut through the cheap paper hotdog/fries container they served my burger on. Poo on me.

I also don't know if I came on a bad day or not, but this place served me THE blandest chili I've ever tasted in my life. I seriously kid you not, the chili had less flavor than the vegan chili that comes in those green cans that you can buy from costco. So given the nature of chili to overpower any flavor it comes in contact with, my chili cheeseburger just tasted like one big bland chili with small chunks of meat and bread--if there was an accurate numeric system to rate how tastes blend together to create food orgy inside one's mouth ranging from a scale from 1-10, the burger gets a solid -99999999 from me.

The only thing that made my eating experience here remotely enjoyable was the fact that they had diet coke and the fact that I came here with good company; if I had come here alone after following the "hype" this place apparently gets, I most definitely would have given this place my first one star review.
author: Scott S.

description:
Chilli, hot dogs, burgers in sour dough bread, etc etc you get the picture. I'm sad about this place though. I hope rumors are not true, but it's quite evident that it may soon be gone along with the demolition and construction of the pier. An ever lasting piece of history sitting right here where you can get some decent comfort food. I think the folks who run this place occasionally changes, but the food is consistent. I personally love their burgers that come in sour dough bread. It's thin, and the bread is sometimes tough. It may not appeal to all, but they definitely get away with it. A cup of yummy fries to go with your order and a can of coke and you can say that you had a great day while you had lunch on the bay :) 

PS: it's been a good year since I've been back, but I hope most people realized how awesome their candy display was ( displaying candy wrappers with the prices to show what they've got in stock).
author: Monina C.

description:
At Cal football games there is a chant we have when we beat a higher ranked team: Over-rated! Over-rated! 

That's sort of how I feel about Red's. I always hear people throw it in as one of their favorite burgers in SF. I find that to be a questionable statement but to each their own. 

Yes, it was on Bourdain and I love No Reservations but the only thing I found to be incredibly tasty at Red's was the fries. 

I'm definitely willing to check it out again but I was not blown away by my first visit. 

Was it good? Yes. The best? The jury is still out on that question.
author: Carlos A.

description: First let me say what a great location to go for breakfast... or any meal...right on the bay, you can sit inside or outside on the deck, fabulous views and inside wonderful historical photos. Would be perfect place to go before a game. We went for breakfast, so we can't speak for the lunch or dinner menus. Breakfast menu was limited and the food was just ok. Pancakes ok, syrup had an odd taste, bacon and sausages were good, breakfast quesadilla was ok, but the tortilla didn't seem fresh. Everyone enjoyed the eggs and chile, the coffee was good. Mostly I loved the location. Might not go back for breakfast, but would try lunch.
author: Brekkie D.

description: Best fish and chips I've ever had. Out office used to be in SOMA and we ate at Red's weekly. Now that we're in the Financial District, it's a good 20-minute walk. So we only go every couple weeks. Definitely worth the walk at lunch time!
author: John P.

description:
We love to take our friends who visit us from out of town here. Reds is the kind of place that all types of people and  all personalities will love. You can't beat the prices, there is always a lively energy, you can sit indoors or out and you really can't beat the food. 

The cheeseburgers served on rolls are amazing the chili cheese fries are SO good! They have a full bar and sell PBR's by the bucket! Yup! 

On a nice day its a great place to sit under the bay bridge sip a bloodymary and eat some good food. 

As Anthony Bourdain put it, "its a great antidote for Alice Waters"
author: Tawnya C.

description:
I've stopped by here a few times for random things like coffee, a burger, the bathroom, and have had a nice experience each time. 

You can't beat the outside seating area, and their basic burger is really yummy. I love that they serve it on a roll instead of a bun, but I think the patty could use to be a little bigger to fill out the roll. But it is delicious. 
The coffee is reasonable priced, and so are some of the beers. They have a bar out on the patio too, separate from the dining room, and I love that too.
I would just love to see the guys at the counter be a little friendlier. They just don't smile or small talk or joke or anything. It's just a little cut and dry. My last visit there was right after the Giants game, where we won, and it would be nice if the people working a stones throw away from the stadium actually cared that their home team just won. 

Anyway, great place, I'll be back.
author: Reyna O.

description:
After a day walking the pier before the Giants vs. Dodgers game yesterday, we ended up here before the game because..

A) it was right next to where we parked
B) the weather was gorgeous so how could you not want to lounge outside?
C) when you are having one of the best day ever, it doesn't matter where you are

The boyfriend got our drinks (mine a diet soda).  We sat and chilled for a short period of time whilst our boy hung out in his stroller w/o making a peep.  I kind of forgot what we talked about... I remember him calling those pigeons "turkeys" and commented on some lady's haircut being like Rod Stewart (haha).  

Oh yeah.. soda refills are $1.  

Thanks to him, I got that Barfly badge even though I don't drink.
author: Tram N.

description:
It looks like a hole in the wall but the food is so good!

Amazing food and such great service (even though you kind of have to do some of the work yourself). The food came out fast and it was delicious! 

We sat outside on the pier in the back and the only thing to be cautious about is the birds flying around.
author: Nilija F.

description:
Just moved to SF, had time before work so I went around the neighborhood. Stumbled upon this little shack, and it was wonderful.  I had the opportunity to be there on their special corned beef has breakfast sandwich day. What made my morning is having been able to eat out on the deck with a view of the bay bridge. It was spectacular, and made my morning better. 

Coffee here is ok, nothing to special. I enjoyed the atmosphere, it really fits the bay / water life.
author: Nye T.

description: We were told to stop here by a friend. Total hole in the wall place! Don't let the outside look hold you back. It may look run down but it's so cool! We went in for breakfast before a Giants game. I had the pancake plate and my husband had corned beef hash plate. Everything was delicious! After the game we stopped by for a drink. There's a little bar out back. Margarita and a beer. Fun place!
author: Jessica F.

description: Last of the old waterfront dives. If you want bad, overpriced food in a dirty greasy spoon, this is the place. Years ago before the Port of SF crashed, it was fun for cheap burgers and hot dogs with a Bay view, but now they've gone tourist trap-trendy while still serving the same lousy food. I don't know how this dump stays open.
author: Pam J.

description:
Fun place to stop for beers, burgers and fries after work (or before a game). Super casual environment, great location by the water on Embarcadero. Huge outside seating area with long tables and umbrellas. It's conveniently located by a ton of great businesses and homes, so naturally, it gets busy after 5PM. Be prepared to either get there early, or fight someone for a place to sit. 

Yummy, all american menu. Cheese burgers were great, and served exactly as they should be - simple. I'm a sucker for fries, and the fries at Red's were stellar - I had to get two orders :) 

Oh, and they're dog friendly btw.
author: Lacey H.

description:
It's a hole in the wall underneath the Bay Bridge..... People have been going in and out of this place as far as i  can remember.  I bet pops grabbed something here back in his day !  lol   
This is no frills place to go to Hamburger, onions, mustard and cheese on sourdough bread if you want mayo, catchup they come in packs and no lettuce or tomatos.  They have combos with either a soda or a beer....   If in the area why not if your in the mood for a burger
author: Mark G.

description:
This morning I had one of the best breakfasts that I've ever had "2 eggs  with chili" kindda like HUEVOS RANCHEROS  with a hash brown on the side and a tortilla.  I really love the vibe of the place I tried eating outside but I was a bit cold so I went inside and the decoration ( old but colorful ) makes it a really nice place to eat while admiring the history of Sf on the walls  and looking through the window at the bay bridge another thing... the staff was very friendly too. 

I will most definitely be coming back :)
author: Ricardo V.

description: My favorite go to spot in the city . Always good food and friendly customer service .
author: Stacy A.

description:
A san francisco institution! a must stop before or after a Giant's game.  I love it here for the ambiance, the feel of the place on a crowded pre-game day...
but lets not kid ourselves, the food is nothing special. but you dont come here for the food, you come here to get some beers and a burger before a game, shoot the shit with some Giants fans, taunt the tourists in shorts freezing their asses off and enjoy a lovely view of the bay and the seagulls harassing you for your meal.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Woot woot for the breakfast sandwich! 
We came here this morning and all four of us got the breakfast sandwich with sausage. Very good!! Not too healthy but why not, it was one of those weekends we wanted to enjoy ! =)
This place was on TV too (Anthony Bourdain).
Cute little place by the water. On a good day you can sit in the back, outside overlooking the bay bridge. It can get a little windy, so watch out for the umbrellas (one of them fell and almost cut our heads off!).
Place reminds me an old, rusty fisherman's restaurant.. i loved it.
I'd go back .
author: C A.

description:
Dem fries are amazing. 

After the Giants Fan Fest, we were hungry and decided to take the very short drive here. They gotta have the best parking lot in they city. You can't beat the view of the Bay and the Bay Bridge in the background. 

There's plenty of outdoor seating but you gotta watch our for pigeons and seagulls above you. You better check to make sure that white stuff on your burger is mayo if you decide to eat Al Fresco. 

We got two Double Cheeseburgers with Fries, a Chili Double Cheeseburger and a side order of Chili Fries. Damn, that's a lot of double and chili in one sentence. I like my fries crunchy and more on the overcooked side and their fries are definitely up there with my standards. Man, I couldn't stop popping them in my mouth. 

This place is quite a character, and they also have characters working here. Speaking of, they were fast, friendly and efficient. Gotta love the fact that they were all Manny Pacquiao fans as well. 

Oh, did someone mention that Anthony Bourdain was here, too?
author: John G.

description:
Simple no frills place to grab a greasy burger and a beer before a Giants game.  Location is great and the service is friendly so why only 3 stars? Well, it was $23 for 2 double cheeseburgers and 1 order of onion rings. Add another $20 for 4 small 8 oz cups of Anchor steam, the first one was finished while waiting for our food to come out. Spending nearly $50 here for what we got makes this a 3 star instead of a 4 star spot.  
This is one of those spots where you will end up at again just because of the convenience and location, plus first timers always want to come here because of the SF episode of No Reservations.
author: Chong K.

description:
This is a great place to stop for some drinks on a sunny day or before a game! While I only had fries, the burgers looked fantastic! Not a huge menu, but reasonably priced given the location and all the deep fried goodness looked delicious. 

My favorite part? Huge, dog-friendly patio and $3 Rolling Rock cans. We sat out there for hours yesterday soaking up some sun while the rest of this city was foggy and grey. 

They also have a brunch menu... which I will gladly check out sometime. 

Basically... if you're looking for a decent patio on the water with cheap beers, look no further!
author: Jess K.

description: The breakfast is a bit meh.  The eggs were fine but the hash browns were a bit soggy.  The coffee was Luke warm.
author: Steven L.

description:
This is a rare find in SF - good food, cheap prices, great view and easy parking (there is a paid parking lot right next door with $6 flat rate on the weekends). It literally looks like a shack from the outside, but there are actually 3 rooms - the dining room up front, covered bar further back, and an outdoor area where you can dine with a great view of the bay.

Just don't plan on making a long drive afterwards, especially if you order the corned beef hash with eggs on top. (I think this was about $6-7ish, with generous portions.) The food is pretty good, but the combination of my dish plus two bloody marys makes for a damn serious laxative.
author: Aivy C.

description: This is a GREAT place to grab breakfast or lunch on the weekends.  They serve breakfast until 11a.  I thought this was a specialty coffee house, but it's a food place.  Low-key and a great patio in the back with a fantastic view of the Bay Bridge, bay and Embarcadero.  People were drinking beers at 11a and eating chili cheese fries!  We had the breakfast quesadilla with sausage and breakfast sandwich with bacon on rye.  Both were pretty good.  The coffee was just ok, nothing special at $1.75 a cup.
author: Chris L.

description:
Talk About History

There's pictures all around the place of historical San Francisco. It's amazing to see how different the city was years ago yet still see Red's Java House there. Weekly trivia questions make it a fun place to visit.

My main reason for going here are the breakfast sandwiches. I'm not a huge fan of their lunch but I still go there once in a while.

On game days this place literally explodes... and for good reason. They have $2-3 domestics and it's right next to one of the main event parking lots all while being a short walk to AT&T Park.

Bloody Mary's are pretty good as well (:

nom nom nom
author: Som K.

description: It's the most disgusting greasy burger on a tough piece of sourdough that I keep coming back for like a punch in the face.  Maybe it's because this is my go-to stop coming off a long bike ride for refueling.  Maybe because its the mechanical water front view.  Or maybe its the friendly surly staff.  I don't know.  It's difficult to say. Oh and order the fries, dont be surprised if you find an onion ring or two in the mix.  Variety is the spice...
author: David S.

description:
This shack on the Embarcadero isn't fancy, but it is a terrific experience.  You can come here for a great breakfast (albeit a very limited menu) and sit outside with a view of the Bay Bridge.  Or you can visit for the small but full-service bar in the tent behind the small restaurant.  

We've been impressed with the food.  Nothing fancy, but it's well made and fresh.

When you eat here, you do feel as if you're eating in a part of San Francisco history.  And if you're driving, check out the free parking adjacent to the restaurant!
author: Augie R.

description:
Hole in the wall kind of place.

Food was OK. - pretty greasy.
Nice selection of beer.
Great view in the outdoor patio, relaxing~
author: Sun H.

description:
I've long stayed away from this place..the signage, "Red's Java House" really says, "all sinners welcome"

Today..after a long run...my bff and I decided to take a walk down the Embarcadero to check out Sunday Streets..

"Hell"..I thought.. Life is short..and I should satisfy my craving for a meaty burger with just that...

We rolled into Reds... I ordered a hamburger with beer...a cold Corona...and fries of course.

The burger was solid..but missing my favorite condiments--lettuce and tomato..and I agree with other yelpers..the meat to bread ratio was unfavorable...The fries were tasty and crispy..just the way I like it.

While this will not become a habit any time soon..I do look forward to another visit to Reds on a warm sunny day.
author: Mimi T.

description: Great place for breakfast or lunch. Really nice friendly staff, great breakfast, fantastic looking fish and chips. Wish u could have breakfast and lunch at the same time. Not fancy but clean and nice outdoor deck. I highly recommend it!
author: Michele L.

description:
The food will make you actually sick. Filthy kitchen, filthy staff. Awful food, frozen food, funk this disgusting place. Let the sea drown the employees and all the frozen sick that comes out of this rotten hole of a cave.

It took us 20 minutes to get to the front of the line to order, this wouldn't be a big deal  but we were the 5th people in line. The cashier chatted with his buddy's the entire time while we waited. Luckily during this time we saw the cooks behind the counter heat up frozen fries, frozen onion rings, frozen patties, frozen bread, frozen fish, frozen sick. 

As I ate I saw the cook walk to the back patio smoke a cigarette then walk right back into the kitchen without washing his hands. As soon as I left this garbage dump I wished I could have gone back and thrown up my filth back in to their fryer, I would have if I wasn't sure they'd make a chili out of it. I hope your business drowns in the sea and takes all your dog food with you. Yes I'm talking to every employee of this place, you should know that you peddle garbage, you're all disgusting.
author: Tim G.

description:
There is absolutely nothing remarkable about the burger here. There, I said it.

It's a juicy, yet heartbreakingly underseasoned patty, on a sturdy roll, dripping with the real melted stuff. No frills, no bullsh*t, no kidding. This place is so San Francisco, inside and out -- from the irony of a parking lot stemming from an old dock/pier, to the backyard of the joint facing a gorgeous view of the Bay Bridge, among the incredible soundtrack of your friendly neighborhood seagulls. So awesome.

Your typical skinny crispy fries complement an ice cold Anchor Steam beer -- this magnificent and ingenious combination comes to a great price point. But my five stars come from the heart more than the tongue this time around. It's a cold, pseudo-rainy Sunday evening with the 49ers blaring on the tv on the outside patio. It's me and all the guys working gathered 'round, watching the home team (at home btw) in a great game against the Giants of New York.

And in those moments of shared laughter, enthusiasm, and competitive spirit, I bore witness to some of the funniest, kindest, most accommodating and considerate guys I'd ever encountered in the restaurant biz. Damn, Bourdain, I think you really are on to something here.
author: Monica D.

description: I freakin love this place... There is nothing like sitting under the Bay Bridge with a tasty burger, fries, and a ice cold beer either before the Giants game or for lunch on a weekday. Its my favorite place to get a quick bite to eat with friends or just chill for some quality alone time in the city. I have been coming here for years and will always come back. Thank you Red's !
author: HEINZ M.

description:
On previous trips to Red's I had only ordered breakfast. I went one Sunday morning a little later than usual and decided to order a single cheese burger and fries.
It was a good decision. 

The burger was really simple and delicious, it came with pickles, onion, mustard, cheese, served  on a sourdough roll. It was just what I needed to cure my hangover.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Red's is an SF institution & so is their burger.  There might not be a better place to enjoy a sunny day in the city than on Red's patio, with a cheeseburger, fries, an anchor steam & the beautiful view of the bay.

The burger, any way you get it, is great & simple.  Served on sourdough bread with yellow mustard, onions & pickles.  Lettuce & tomatoes aren't even an option, so no need to ask.

The chili dog is also very good & so are the fish & chips.

Red's is one of my favorite breakfast spots as well, especially when in need of a hangover cure.  The breakfast quesadilla is awesome & the corned beef hash is legendary.  The hash is only served on saturday & sunday & they routinely run out by 10 or 11am on sundays, so get there early.  It's a must try as far as SF breakfast's go.

All in all, Red's is great, whether heading to a Giants game, strolling the embarcadero or in need of some delicious diner fare.
author: Jake M.

description:
Fish & chips, so tender and warm. Just as good as any sit-down, waiter service restaurant. 

Come for the view. Sit inside, sit outside.. it's all good. Take in the sights like a  tender, flaky piece of fish down the gullet. A real SF treat.
author: Ray C.

description: This one is long overdue. This is an SF institution. Breakfast is great but so are their burgers on a sunny day on the deck. Also one of my favorite aspects of this place is the buckets of Rolling Rock. There is nothing quite like a bucket of RR and a burger before a Giants day game down the street.
author: Derek S.

description:
Dayum Yelp is good: as I prepared to write this on Red's page, I was faced with a prominently-displayed banner ad for Weight Watchers.

God bless Red's!

Yes, people, it's a greasy spoon so don't expect "more" but do expect VERY tasty burgers on sourdough for under $5 with a fantastic view, friendly service, and SF history displayed throughout the place. It feels like home all 'round. And while I always fear goiter when I can't get a little greens with my meat (it's true, that policy bit about "no lettuce or tomato served with the burgers"), I also know I have other ways to make that up throughout the day (my medium rare double burger was sooooo good I didn't blink when I transitioned from Patty 1 to Patty 2). So just be clear that the Red's part of your day is for animal protein, pure & simple (purists who argue beer doesn't fit that category have bigger issues to grapple). I'll be back for the egg specials fo' sho.
author: Diane B.

description:
Red's is an institution here in San Francisco. They've been slinging burgers to weary longshoremen since before Calvin Coolidge became the 30th President of the United States of America, and they've been fryin' up fish sticks to the masses along the Embarcadero since before Roy and Walt Disney formed The Walt Disney Company. With that being said, there are a few generations of families that don't know San Francisco without Red's, and for that, I have to tip my hat.

Being on Anthony Bourdain's 'No Reservations' could prove to be one of the worst things that's ever happened to this place. OR, it could be the best. I suppose only time will tell. But what I've noticed since Tony profiled the joint is an increase in patrons and an overrated idea of what's to be expected. It's essentially a fast food joint on the water, and I can't help but believe people are expecting to sink their teeth into the greatest burger in history. That's the double-edged sword in this kind of publicity, as it was a  tad misrepresented, as far as I'm concerned.

This place is an anomaly. If you scan the horizon around the water's edge, you'll notice high rises, yuppies jogging with their iPods, AT&T park, expensive looking condos, the Bay Bridge... and Red's. It sticks out like a sore thumb, it's beat up and sagging like an abandoned spider web... but that's the appeal more so than the food. It's the sole survivor in a sea of gentrification, and it's nice to support such an operation that's been grinding away or nearly 80 years without so much as a face lift along the way.

If you're a Giants fan, you'll have to wait until 2010, but this is one of the best pre-game spots in the area. PBRs are $1.75 and their other beer specials are smokin' as well. Head in an hour before the game, grab a bucket of Milwaukee's finest on the back patio, and get a serious buzz going for the same scratch you'd drop on one Bud Light inside AT&T Park.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
I love Red's...no pretense of anything but a greasy spoon...and it is one of my faves. This is truly one-of-a-kind!!

I had the fish and chips today...with an Anchor beer....hubby got his usual burger. Both were huge, and amazing!! 

We sat outside...and watched the fog lift from the bay...and all the boats heading out.....stunning. 

A great start to a wonderful day!!!
author: Katherine F.

description: UNBELIEVABLE HORRID HAMBURGER!  Frozen and flat as a pancake!  Tasteless. Cold fries and surly service for Nada!  Avoid!
author: Kim S.

description:
When a place has almost 500 reviews and has been featured on an Anthony Bourdain show, the chances are that everything that needs to be said about a place has been said, and said better than I could do.

But what the heck.

The burgers aren't fancy, but they are fantastic. Part of it is the bread instead of bun. It's got a little bite to it, a little chew, but serves as the perfect compliment to the greasy patties inside. Eating on the back patio under the Bay Bridge and tossing fries to the birds. Feeling the crisp breeze off the water - it's just perfect melding of food and atmosphere.

I like to come here for burgers when it's dead. I find the experience a bit more peaceful. So many times, a crowd helps to make a place, but here, it's almost like a cell phone in church. Too many people interrupt my pleasant reveries.
author: Blair M.

description:
I feel tricked by Anthony Bourdain.  He made it so sound absolutely irresistible on TV so I actually made a trip out there.  Aside from the spectacular view, I don't see what the big deal is about the food.  Don't get me wrong, I appreciate simple burgers.  I even appreciate grease-laden, unhealthy burgers as long as the flavor is there.  But unfortunately, this was lacking much.

I got a Cheeseburger and Chili Cheese Fries.  The cheeseburger was very sloppy.  One bite would have a huge chunk of onion and another bite would have nothing.  It's just all over the place and the bread is too thick.  They use a sourdough roll instead and I appreciate the creativity but the patty gets lost.  It's also not flavored well so I used a lot of ketchup and Tapatio.  

The chili cheese fries came out while we were still paying.  I believe they use American cheese slices but the chili wasn't hot enough to melt it completely which was a bummer.  The chili itself was also a bit bland.  The two biggest things this place has got going for it are the local feel and the location.

When I got home, I had to practically run to the bathroom.

BUT LET'S NOT FORGET THE BIGGEST PLUS EVER -- FREE PARKING FOR CUSTOMERS!!!
author: Shannon L.

description: I was on my way to th Giants game and stopped here for fish and chips and a cold one, not bad for 15 bucks on game day, the beer is cold and $4 a bottle, in the stadium it would have been 10 bucks or more, the view is awesome, the crowd was, well, "Giant" haha.  Now if you are coming here on a non game day I really suggest giving this place a try, it's not fancy like other places but than again, neither is the prices, and for a great view of the bay bridge right above you, thats priceless.  I would definitely stop here again, I can't give it a full 5 stars because of the old building etc and the decor but 3 stars is great for a hole in the way place.  YES definitely check this out if you are in town.
author: Wil G.

description: From SoCal up visiting for a few days this spot is bomb. Get here early line gets long. Double cheeseburger, garlic fries and a Budweiser is too good. Definitely somewhere to take on a date like you had it planned for weeks.
author: Dert S.

description:
Small interior but good greasy food style that can be enjoyed outdoors as well. Red's Java House is on the bay but the vie is not great. I suggest sunny day al fresco only. get a burger or breakfast here and don't expect gourmet, just belly filling. The prices are good and the decor is shack.
I'll be back with it.
author: Alexander R.

description: Great burgers and ultra simple place. Typically go here before Giants games to get a good burger which is half the price compared to the ballpark and 10x better. Service is so so but I don't go there for the service.
author: Patrick G.

description: Another lunch at Red's and another stomachache on the way...I can just feel it brewing.  Red's is an old school staple.  Fantastic location on the water, and a nice counterpoint for the Hi Dive next door, which can be pretentious at times.  No frills at Red's, just diner food and cold beer on the water.  Next to a parking lot, but before noon you can use the meters on Embarcadero. Red's has great breakfasts.  Then at 11, they switch to lunch, and the food takes a big dive.  The fish and chips are the best thing on the lunch menu and they are just average.  Red's is famous for the burgers, served on a slab of sourdough...but the sourdough isn't very sour, so it's just a big tough chewy french roll.  Way too much bread and way hard to eat.  No produce for the burgers, so you get mayo, onions, mustard and pickles.  The meat is frozen patties.  No bueno.  $11 for this subpar burger, fries and a drink?  Meh.  Come to Red's in the morning...have a great breakfast and a cocktail and move on....
author: Ken P.

description:
A San Francisco staple...one of the original old dockworkers' joints from back when SoMa/South Beach was a working port and warehousing area. 

Food is what you'd expect, but the patio par and dining area are what make this place special.
author: Nora H.

description:
A hot wave of greasy smoke greeted us as we entered the door of Red's Java House on a recent Sunday afternoon on our way to the game. In front of us stood a line of people who appeared waiting in limbo. Service was moving at a snails pace. I grabbed a table out back and tried not to inhale the putrid odor of garbage, beer, and the port-o-potty stationed nearby. I ordered a hot dog and what I got was by all accounts  THE worst excuse for a hot dog I have ever come across. Served on a shitty, Wonderbread type bun, it was swimming in bright yellow deli mustard accompanied by chopped onions! Who the FUCK puts onions on a hot dog? 
My companion ordered a burger, if you could call it that. It was a shit-mess of meat, cheese on a square roll. REDS JAVA HOUSE is a SHIT HOLE and the Board of Health should be called immediately before someone gets sick.
author: Brian R.

description: Red's has a bit of a soft spot to me. my dad has been taking me there for years when i was a kid, even before AT&T Park existed, before South Market became the thriving neighborhood it is today, before it was featured on Anthony Bourdain's show. it doesn't try to be a place it's not; what you see it what you get. i guess you can say it's a man's man place to grab a quick burger or hotdog before a Giants game. of course, it's crowded during the baseball season, so stop by year 'round. honestly, if i was going to get a meal in the area before the game, i'd chose to go there than any other place. it's not for everyone; similar to pure tailgate food only done better.
author: Mike C.

description:
The food is not super fancy but it does the job!!

Was not heckled too much as we were Dodger fans in complete Dodger gear. Good place to drink and talk or look at sports.

I have never had a Hamburger on Sourdough! Very different.
author: Camille I.

description:
This is a great place to come for good food and drinks before the Giants Game. I've been here a few times last season and went back this season and I have to say it definitely a good dive bar. 

The outdoor patio area is my favorite on a nice day in the city, you enjoy a drink outside and catch up with friends. It can get busy where you might find yourself having to stand around waiting for a table and chairs but you have chance to enjoy the water while you wait. 

The drinks are reasonable price, 6 can of PBR for only $12, that's good especially being so close to the stadium. 

I would definitely have to recommend this place if you're looking for a nice chill place to enjoy some food and drinks before a game or even just a day in the city
author: Krystal F.

description: Such a legendary SF dive, which became a regular hangout for me when the new baseball park was built & opened 12 years ago.  There is no finer place to hang out before a baseball game- affordable & high quality drafts and bottles available, with a nice outdoor seating area.  The food is simple and greasy, and super cheap- burgers, dogs, onion rings, fries etc.  Don't come looking for the vegan tofu burgers....I've gravitated away from Red's over the years only because I'm usually looking for better food before the games, however if it's a 'beer-only' pre-game, or if I'm parking on the pier next door, I'll always stop at Red's for a pint, a pitcher, or more...
author: Andy S.

description: What part of "java" did Rfamosoed's Java House not get?? A very misleading disappointment on a chilly day.
author: Genevieve G.

description: I'm sorry but the the food is really bland I had the chili cheese burger and the chili to begin with. didn't taste like a really homemade chili more of a chili out of a can......the Burger patty felt like it was from a middle school kitchen patty that u get from the freezer....the bread was really good tho and crunchy and the staff are friendly that's why I gave it a two star max
author: Jahaziel A.

description: I have lived across from Reds and have been a loyal patron for 15 years.  I love this place for what it is:  A great neighborhood spot with a simple, no frills menu, and good food.  This review is for what it has become.  I just can't understand why they keep raising prices.  $8.17 for a tuna salad sandwich is just $3 too much.  I was told that the price increase was to "squeeze as much money out of it before it closes for the Warriors Arena construction".  Well I get that.  I understand.  However, that project ain't happening so please, please ROLL YOUR PRICES BACK.  When you price your food the same as the very upscale and delicious options at the Ferry Building, then you are going to lose your local customers.  Price your food for what it is.  Simple and good, with no frills.  The price should reflect what you get.
author: Barrett F.

description:
Finally!!!!!!! Woohoo
I made my way over to this place after visiting a customer near by.  Ordered away from the menu *tuna melt* 
When this sandwich came out and the server handed me the melt, I nearly dropped it. It was so fricken heavy.  Tuna was straight oozing out of all sides, cheese was melted perfectly.  For a measly $5 this sandwich was more than enough for 2-3 people.
author: Dennis d.

description:
On the wall at Red's, you will find a picture of my grandfather getting roughed up by the cops.  Seriously.

He was an organizer for the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) -- and a bit of a local celeb back in his day.  And he's up there on the wall with Tony Bourdain and all the famous people, because Red's is one of the few places left that still honors our waterfront's working past.  Too many of us have forgotten the men who sweated and toiled before those giant cranes across the bay took over the job.  Red's hasn't.  Those fellas were their customers.

That's the thing:  Red's isn't trying to entice tourists, it isn't trying to be kitsch.  It's a longshoremen's lunch counter.  Thassit.

You don't want to eat and drink like a longshoreman?  Feel free to take your ascot to one of the 319 other establishments on todays' waterfront -- and enjoy your appletini.  Heck, I do that sometimes myself.  But that's not Red's.  At Red's, it's all about fish and chips and beer.

This is a place where working men used to let off steam -- and still do.  Not all of them are manual laborers anymore, not all of them are even men anymore.  And thankfully, most of them aren't getting hassled by the police for demanding a living wage and humane working conditions (thank you, Grandpa Gene!).  But this is a special place where the spirit lives on.
author: Rosie W.

description: Our regular pre-gaming spot before a SF Giants game. Food is ok. Most everything is fried. The healthiest choice is beer.
author: Jojo G.

description:
Breakfast sandwich with bacon, extremely greasy. I suppose this would be great if you have the worst hang over in known history.

Made the mistake of sitting outside, it was a cross between a favela and the toilets at kilowatt.

Can't say I'd ever come back here not blacked out.
author: Jesse S.

description:
Good breakfast, great location, and outstanding service.  Worth the drive from the east bay...... Not fancy (plastic fork/knives) so come very casual and then walk it off by heading to the Ferry building to take advantage of the weekend end farmers market.


3/10/12
author: V J.

description:
I heard of this place about nine years ago.  I finally had a chance to check it out.  The verdict?  Meh.

Had the double cheeseburger, fries and drink combo for $8.  Pretty good deal.  The burger is massive and comes on a huge piece of sourdough bread that does a good job of soaking up the grease.  The beef, in a way, reminded me of Mickey D's patties.   Also, I forget how much I enjoy lettuce and tomatoes on burgers until I don't get that option.

The fries were plentiful but again nothing to write home about.

Old school, divey, feel is nice though.  Probably more 3* but felt that the long wait and letdown made me drop it a notch.
author: F. P.

description:
One of my favorite places in the city. Doesn't hurt that its halfway between my office and the ballpark, but that's only the tip of the iceberg. Despite its small external appearance, there is plenty of outdoor seating right on the water and a good amount inside too. The best bet in the bar in the back is the bucket of PBRs or Rolling Rocks (6 for 12 bucks). Closing time says 5 PM but on gamedays that seems flexible

Inside I've got nothing but nice things to say about the burgers. I usually go for the double cheeseburger. They sandwich the patties between giant sourdough roll halves and its a perfect tipsy dinner option before heading to the game
author: Taylor C.

description: Yum! Reds is the only place to eat before or after a Giants game! There burgers are served on amazing sourdough and there fries are incredible! And they sell beer! Cheep beer!
author: Caitlin L.

description: love this place a classic waterfront san francisco dive restraunt love the food great service good place to catch a meal before a giants game
author: Leigh G.

description:
Bad. I agree with Justin S: Just because it's an oldie doesn't mean it's a goodie. The food was drenched with viscous grease, the cheese was processed plastic and the interior not rustic enough to befit the age of the establishment.

When you're walking down the Embarcadero...keep on walking.
author: Jay A.

description: Delicious sour dough bun burgers. Nothing fancy, but definitely always hits the spot. Their fries are also always piping hot and fresh. If you're on your way to the game, save yourself some money and eat here before.
author: Jay T.

description:
I swear to g-d that Red's gets better every time I go there. The menu is still simple and filled with tasty food, and the price aint bad, either.

The bar in back is great for summer sessions. They also do specials on Pabst, which the hipster, er, working class white kid in me can't get enough of.
author: Wes T.

description: We went here after kayaking in McCovey Cove. They had the game playing, beer flowing, and the greasy cheeseburger was awesome. It's right on the Embarcadero and has patio seating. It looks old but it serves it's purpose.
author: Marty J.

description: Um we went for happy hour after work and last call was at 6pm for alcohol.. and food was out of the question as the kitchen was already closed. They wouldn't let our friend in because it was 6:05 while we were still lounging in the back. Yikes.
author: Vol T.

description:
I had some time to kill today, and this place looked just right: local, eclectic, and (most importantly to my rumbling stomach) fast.  

I ordered up the fish and chips and a coke, and was pleased to see that the fish were real big chunks of fried and battered goodness on a decent sized bed of fries.  

Hot, a little greasy, a bit chewy, and a tad salty.  Perfection, and accompanied by the raucous and persistent music of several nappy pigeons, a scrubby seagull or three, and a teensy little brown bird who actually flew up onto my table, begging for food as I sat out back, enjoying the view of the bay.  

This place is my new greasy guilty pleasure.
author: Nik R.

description:
Since high school, I've been going to Red's for one reason: the view. There's nothing like eating Red's greasy, grubby food under the view of the Bay Bridge on a sunny day. Don't come expecting Alice Waters on the Embarcadero. Red's is a no-frills shack with dilapidated tables, pigeons and seagulls, and the occasional pungent smell from the Bay to boot. 

I usually order a Cheeseburger with fries. The cheeseburger is really basic: meat, cheese, tomatoes, pickles, mustard, ketchup, and onions. No lettuce.  It's not the best burger in SF, but the Sourdough roll makes it a uniquely SF burger.  The rest of the menu is simple, and the guys behind the counters can be real characters. 

I've been going to Red's long before Anthony Bourdain brought attention to it, and I'll keep going there long after the hype as has died down and it remains, a true San Francisco joint.
author: Monelle A.

description: Great breakfast sandwiches. Had one with bacon and one with sausage. This is an old school dive breakfast joint where you can wash away the night with some good old fashioned grease in you stomach. And the coffee is pretty good too.
author: Brian A.

description:
I've always wanted to get my drink on at Momo's before a game, but it's always unbelievably packed and I'm not exactly a people person. However, Red's Java House has always caught my attention with its outdoor patio and pitchers of beer flowing freely.  The front houses a small diner with burgers, hot dogs, and sandwiches.  The back of the Java House has a full bar and an outdoor patio.

Happy Hour starts at 5pm and for $13 you can get yourself a pitcher of domestic draft.  Or for about the same price, you can get yourself a bucket of Pabst Blue Ribbon.  For those looking for a stronger concoction, mixed drinks are available and are reasonably priced. After a pitcher or two of beer, you find your stomach rumbling, so I grabbed myself a hot dog from the front for about $3.  The hot dog wasn't bad, but wasn't great, just about right from a place like Red's.  It was a nice compliment to the beer before the game.

If you have some time for a beer and a bite before a game, check out Red's, it's got some history and more importantly it won't break your wallet.

Note:  The bar closes at 7pm.
author: Alexander E.

description:
You have got to love a place that proudly announces that they do not serve tomatoes or lettuce on their burgers. And no, the burgers are not lacking any flavor because of this rule. The burgers come on a fresh sourdough roll (oh so SF!) with american cheese, onions and pickles. They are perfect and you shouldn't try to mess with them!

You have got to check out this place, not just because Anthony Bordain thinks you should, but because it is cheap, has outdoor seating, is fast and is just downright delicious.
author: Caitlin H.

description:
So you want to eat by the waterfront and don't want to pay a ton of money? Go to Red's!

Listen, they aren't pretending to be fancy so don't expect table service or, really, much service at all. Also, don't expect lettuce or tomato on your burger. You will get one burger, straight up, with onions and pickles and mustard on a sourdough roll. And you will like it. 

The bar out back is awesome. $7 margaritas (and they pack a punch, lemme tell ya) and all the sun you can soak in. The view is partially parking lot but you can still see the bridge and the sailboats passing by. The patio is also dog friendly, or I assumed it was since I was definitely sitting next to some kind of pitbull meet-up the last time I was by. 

Cute dogs (possibly), good meat, and stiff drinks with a view? You know you want to try this place out.
author: Madeline N.

description: The location and bar is cool, but the food isn't too good. My friends and I went here because we were going to go hard knox cafe but the wait was too long so we decided on here. The location and the view of the bridge is cool but that food wasn't that good. My friend ordered a burger and it didn't look that good. I ordered chili haerous and it was just decent. cool location and nice view of the bay bridge though!
author: Brian B.

description: Fun place, on the water, basic, but the food is good, and the coffee is too!  Is closed occasionally for special private parties, but when open, worth stopping in to try a burger...on sourdough...be ready for a good, moist, greasy burger!
author: R J.

description:
Note that I've only ever eaten the fish & chips here, with a side of onion rings.

Food: Greasy, fried, but as expected. If you want something filling and diner-esque, you've come to the right place. Who wouldn't want fish & chips right on the pier?

Ambiance: Red's is definitely a diner. You can sit at chairs and tables (or one big bench if you like) inside, or else out on the patio behind the restaurant. The latter option gives you good views of the Bay, the Bay Bridge, and Oakland off in the distance. On sunny days it's really quite pleasant.

Service: In terms of friendliness, this isn't the place to go (I always get bemused looks when I smile at the wait staff). No one's rude, per se, so I suppose this really does complete the entire diner experience. My food's always correctly done and prompt, which is important as I tend to take it to go.

Overall: 3 = A-OK.  It's close to work, with quick service. Not the best fish & chips I've ever had, but it hits the spot and gets the job done.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Good beers by the pitcher. Full bar. Patio on the bay. Sign me up!!
